item.title: Serbian Lawmakers Approve Luxury Trump Hotel on Historic Bombing Site
item.description: Despite a fraud investigation into officials who endorsed the project, Parliament used an extraordinary provision in the Constitution to push the plans through.

item.title: Leaders at COP30 Climate Summit in Belém Focus on the Rising Toll of Warming
item.description: “All we have to do is look outside,” one delegate said. “The sea rises, the coral dies.”

item.title: 4 Arrested Over Disruption of Israeli Orchestra’s Concert
item.description: Several audience members shouted or lit flares as the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra performed in Paris. After the concert, the ensemble received 10 minutes of applause and played the Israeli national anthem.

item.title: U.S. Wants Security Council to Adopt Trump Plan for Gaza
item.description: The alternative, Ambassador Michael Waltz bluntly told diplomats, was to watch the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas give way to a return to war.

item.title: As Saudi Arabia Cracks Down on Drugs, Executions Near a Record High
item.description: Facing an influx of amphetamines, the kingdom has put hundreds of people to death, many of them foreigners convicted of low-level smuggling.

item.title: COP30 Begins With U.S. Allies and Rivals Alike Calling for Action
item.description: The calls for action on opening day stood in sharp contrast to the position of the President Trump, who has called global warming a “con job.”

item.title: Fatos Nano, Albanian Leader in Era of Chaos and Transition, Dies at 73
item.description: A consummate political survivor during his country’s shift from brutal communist regime to flawed democracy, he served three stints as prime minister.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Scar Canadian City Where Cars Have Been Made for Decades
item.description: An automaker’s decision to shift Canadian jobs to the United States has left workers in Brampton, Ontario, feeling betrayed and angry.

item.title: Trump Officials Accused of Bullying Tactics to Kill a Climate Measure
item.description: Nations were poised to approve the first fee on pollution from ships. That’s when the Trump administration began the threats.

item.title: Russian Sanctions Risk Straining Trump’s Chummy Relationship With Hungarian Leader
item.description: New U.S. penalties on Russian energy could be a sticking point as President Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary meet.

item.title: Philippines Faces Grim Typhoon Aftermath as Another Storm Nears
item.description: The death toll for Typhoon Kalmaegi rose into the triple digits, and the country is bracing for another cyclone expected this weekend.

item.title: Why Germany Is Still Divided When It Comes to Russia
item.description: Many East Germans are more sympathetic toward Moscow than their western compatriots, reflecting decades of Soviet ties and disillusionment since reunification.

item.title: Russian Jailed for Placing Tiny Antiwar Signs in a Market Says She Would Do it Again
item.description: Freed in a major prisoner swap, Aleksandra Skochilenko said “the values of freedom of speech, of peace, could be more important than spending even 10 years in jail.”

item.title: Former King of Spain, Juan Carlos, Details Death of Brother in Memoir
item.description: He wrote about the accident that killed his brother nearly 70 years ago. The book also describes his respect for Gen. Francisco Franco, the former dictator.

item.title: In China, Victims of Abuse Are Told to ‘Keep It in the Family’
item.description: Cases of domestic violence in China point to a legal system that looks good on paper but is failing victims because of a lack of resources and political will.

item.title: China’s New Aircraft Carrier Enters Service, a Sign of Naval Ambitions
item.description: The Fujian, China’s most advanced carrier, went into official service this week. It brings the country closer to challenging U.S. naval dominance.

item.title: Testosterone and Women’s Sex Drive
item.description: My colleague Susan Dominus discusses her reporting on women who are taking testosterone — in some cases lots of it.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Removes Syria’s President From Sanctions List
item.description: The decision comes days before the Syrian president, Ahmed al-Shara, is expected in Washington for the first time since he came to power.

item.title: How Radio Traffic Let Us Track U.S. Drones in the Caribbean
item.description: The U.S. military’s buildup near Venezuela has been rapidly growing and changing. Riley Mellen, from Visual Investigations, describes what’s visible, and audible, about the deployment.

item.title: Sexual Assault of Mexico’s President Exposes Challenges of Her Equality Push
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum was groped on the street this week, in an episode that set off a national conversation about what has and has not changed since Mexico elected its first female leader.

item.title: Canada Is About to Lose Its Status as Having Eliminated Measles
item.description: One province with an outsize number of cases has seen a collision of politics and public health policy.

item.title: U.S. Sends Attack Aircraft to El Salvador Amid Regional Troop Buildup
item.description: A New York Times analysis of satellite imagery and air traffic control communications found that U.S. military planes began operating out of the Central American country in mid-October.

item.title: Boiler Tower at Power Plant in South Korea Collapses
item.description: The structure was being demolished when it collapsed. One person was killed, two were rescued, and several more were believed to still be buried.

item.title: Libya Detains Prison Director Wanted for Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: Osama Elmasry Njeem was arrested in Italy in January but sent back to Libya, as critics accused the Italian government of failing to stand up for human rights.

item.title: Ed Moloney, Chronicler of the Troubles in Northern Ireland, Dies at 77
item.description: He wrote a history of the Irish Republican Army and directed a project that secretly collected oral histories of paramilitary fighters.

item.title: Paramilitary Accepts Sudan Truce Plan, but the Military Has Not
item.description: The R.S.F. paramilitary group, facing growing condemnation for atrocities in Darfur, said it had agreed to a cease-fire proposal, but it is not yet clear what the military will do.

item.title: Iran Sentences Iranian American Jewish Man to Prison, Family Says
item.description: Kamran Hekmati of Long Island was arrested for visiting Israel 13 years ago to celebrate his son’s bar mitzvah, they said.

item.title: Why Is Trump Threatening to Intervene In Nigeria?
item.description: President Trump has threatened to send troops to Nigeria, where he says Christianity faces an “existential threat,” an accusation that Nigeria has denied. Ruth Maclean, our West Africa bureau chief, describes how the violence in Nigeria is affecting people of all religions, not only Christians.

item.title: Scores of Palestinian Militants Still in Israeli-Controlled Parts of Gaza, Officials Say
item.description: At least some of the fighters are believed to be in the enclave’s vast tunnel network, marooned behind the “yellow line” that Israeli forces withdrew to as part of the cease-fire.

item.title: Climate Diplomacy and Hardball Tactics
item.description: With this year’s global climate summit opening in Brazil, we offer a glimpse of how the Trump administration sometimes operates behind closed doors.

item.title: Lula Hitches a Ride to the COP30 Climate Talks in a Chinese E.V.
item.description: The climate-friendly ride, part of a fleet assembled to shuttle delegations to the gathering in Brazil, sent a clear signal: China is making inroads in Latin America.

item.title: Mamdani’s Global Roots
item.description: There’s been outsize international attention on the next mayor of New York City. Today, I write about why.

item.title: What Scientists Are Learning From Brain Organoids
item.description: Lab-grown “reductionist replicas” of the human brain are helping scientists understand fetal development and cognitive disorders, including autism. But ethical questions loom.

item.title: ‘Broken My Hope’: Trump’s Move to Slash Refugee Arrivals Ricochets Widely
item.description: President Trump’s policy has shut the door on all but a tiny fraction of people across the world seeking refuge in the United States from conflict, persecution or both.

item.title: Russia Close to Its Biggest Capture of a Ukrainian City Since 2023
item.description: The Kremlin is focusing its fire on Pokrovsk, a gateway to the Donetsk region, which Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, has long coveted.

item.title: Angelina Jolie’s Driver in Ukraine Is Taken Away for the Draft
item.description: A frontline visit to bring attention to Russian drone attacks on civilians sheds an inadvertent light on the Ukrainian Army’s troop shortages.

item.title: Mexico’s President Presses Charges Against Man Who Groped Her on the Street
item.description: A video of a man touching Mexico’s first female president, Claudia Sheinbaum, shocked many Mexicans but did not surprise them. “It’s so common,” one woman said.

item.title: On Prince Andrews Road, a Frustrating Effort to Get a New Address
item.description: Villagers in Hellesdon, England, are pushing to change the name, but local bureaucracy makes it difficult.

item.title: Her Research Could Improve Training For Service Dogs
item.description: “This is a type of science that has an impact that most people could see in their homes,” said Erin Hecht, a canine researcher at Harvard. “Now there’s just no money.”

item.title: Bookstores on Edge as Kremlin Sets Sights on Policing Books
item.description: Restrictions on publishers and sellers have grown more severe. Volumes are being pulled from shelves or redacted like secret documents, but bookstores remain important sources of community.

item.title: The U.S. Is Skipping This Year’s Climate Summit. For Many, That’s OK.
item.description: World leaders, gathering in Brazil, will try to agree on new, more ambitious plans to cut greenhouse gases.

item.title: COP30 U.N. Climate Talks Are Starting in Brazil. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Diplomats and leaders from around the world are gathering on the edge of the Amazon rainforest for annual talks on how to limit global warming.

item.title: Miss Universe Organizer Apologizes After Tirade at Miss Mexico
item.description: Several contestants walked out of a Miss Universe event this week when the pageant director berated Miss Mexico for not taking part in promotional activities.

item.title: Analysis Finds Global Warming Made Hurricane Melissa More Damaging
item.description: Climate change enabled the storm to churn faster and grow more quickly, a rapid analysis found.

item.title: Remains of the Last American Hostage Held in Gaza Returned to Israel
item.description: Israeli officials told Itay Chen’s family last year that he was probably killed on Oct. 7, 2023, but relatives put off mourning until his body had come home.

item.title: Elizabeth Tsurkov Recounts 2 1/2 Years of Captivity
item.description: Elizabeth Tsurkov, a citizen of Israel and Russia, recounts a harrowing story of cruelty, survival, U.S. diplomatic pressure and, finally, release from the grip of a group backed by Iran.

item.title: FIFA Will Award Its Own Peace Prize Next Month in Washington
item.description: Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, has built a close relationship with President Trump, who has groused about not winning the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: U.S. Military Draws Up Nigeria Plans, With Limited Options to Quell Violence
item.description: American forces are unlikely to be able to end a decades-long insurgency in Africa’s most populous country, despite President Trump’s order, officials said.

item.title: Deadly Louisville Air Crash Disrupts One of World’s Busiest Cargo Hubs
item.description: The crash killed nine people and forced a halt to operations at UPS Worldport, a major automated package sorting facility. UPS said that some deliveries could be delayed.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani’s Triumph in the NYC Mayoral Race Evokes Intense Reaction in Israel
item.description: “The Big Apple has fallen,” a right-wing lawmaker said, reflecting broader worries in the Mideast country. Palestinians hailed the election as a sea change in the United States.

item.title: Irish Police Got a Call About a Lion. It Was Actually a Dog Named Mouse.
item.description: A truck driver’s grainy video spurred bewilderment and speculation about a lion roaming in Ireland. Turns out it was a dog with an aggressive haircut.

item.title: Attacked by Swarm of Wasps, American Father and Son Die in Laos
item.description: Daniel Owen, 47, and his son, Cooper, 15, died after being stung dozens of times last month by what appeared to be so-called murder hornets.

item.title: Fire at Retirement Home in Bosnia Kills at Least 11
item.description: The country’s prime minister called the blaze “a disaster of enormous proportions.” The cause was still to be determined.

item.title: What to Know About Kataib Hezbollah, the Iraqi Militia That Held Tsurkov Captive
item.description: Kataib Hezbollah, a hard-line Iraqi militia linked to Iran, held Elizabeth Tsurkov, a citizen of Israel and Russia, hostage for more than two years.

item.title: Mamdani Walks Offstage to Bollywood Song After Victory Speech
item.description: “Dhoom Machale,” a popular Hindi film song played at the end of Zohran Mamdani’s first speech as New York City’s mayor-elect, nodded to his Indian roots.

item.title: Brazil Proposes a New Type of Fund to Protect Tropical Forests
item.description: The multibillion-dollar fund would essentially pay countries to keep forests standing, hoping for success where earlier forest-protection ideas have struggled.

item.title: A Harrowing Escape From the Drone-Infested Hellscape of Ukraine’s Front Lines
item.description: In Ukraine, unmanned weapons hunt the wounded and medics alike. Moving injured soldiers to safety has never been more difficult.
